Washington D.C., May 16, 2018 —
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced fraud charges against three former Constellation Healthcare Technologies Inc. executives who falsified financial and other information they provided to a private firm in the course of negotiating the private firm’s acquisition of a majority stake in Constellation. Houston-based Constellation filed for bankruptcy in March, a little more than a year after the January 2017 acquisition.

According to the SEC’s complaint, the executives convinced a private firm to acquire a majority of Constellation’s equity and provided fake information, including financial statements for three fictitious subsidiaries supposedly acquired for more than $62 million. The complaint alleges that the former executives funded the sham acquisitions with stock sales in London and then diverted the proceeds to themselves. The complaint charges former Constellation chief executive Parmjit (Paul) Parmar, former chief financial officer Sotirios (Sam) Zaharis, and former company secretary Ravi Chivukula. In September 2017, amid concerns about Constellation’s financial condition, Parmar resigned and Zaharis and Chivukula were put on administrative leave.

In our recent note we posited future OSP deals should have superior economics due to
lower costs '(cookie-cutter' software solutions, 'bot' procurement, etc.) compared to
the initial CFC's partnerships (Casino, Sobey's). Our indicative NPV was £73m per future
CFC (75,000 OPW); applying that rule of thumb suggests today's partnership could be
worth up to £1.5bn net to Ocado, i.e. £2.30/sh of value. This morning's action, with
the shares up c.£2.10/sh (+38%) as we write, seems initially comprehensible on this
basis.

capex (each CFC could cost c.$80m to bring online) and lower ongoing capacity fees
(albeit with an NPV neutral effect).

PM11:34am

Fixed Odds Betting Terminal (FOBT) stakes cut to £2
The Department for Digital, Culture, Media & Sport (DCMS) has announced this morning the decision to cut FOBT stakes on B2 machines to £2 ( link) . This has been the most widely discussed topic in the UK gaming sector for the past two years, and today’s announcement brings the debate to a close more than a year after it was originally expected. We believe the investment community has become more cautious on the potential outcome in recent months, with many investors expecting the £2 outcome. Shares in the sector fell sharply at end-April on headlines in the press that furthered this view. However we still expect more downside today.

Plato the Cook Online shopping may not be profitable, but still contribute to covering fixed costs. Also there’s a customer loyalty/retention aspect for in-store, and a big contribution to understanding customer preferences
cracklenpop Any grey on Mothercare?
PM11:35am

What does this mean for stocks?
WMH, PPB and GVC have all put out separate statements estimating the impact. WMH have said after various mitigating measures it expects a £70-100m negative impact to profits (c21% of EBITDA). PPB is the least exposed and the company suggested this could have a £35-46m revenue impact (2-2.6% of group revenue, no comment on profits). GVC (not covered) have stated £120m hit to profits on a fully mitigated basis.

11:35 am
PM11:36am

What next? Shares likely to be down significantly
Shares are likely to be down significantly, with PPB likely to hold up better given lower retail exposure. Companies have already communicated to the market what they expect the impact to be, how they plan to mitigate it, and how many shops they intend to close. WMH has said that c900 shops (38%) of existing estate could become loss making and risk being closed. Previous industry commentary has suggested that a third of all betting shops in the UK could close (see our UBS Evidence Lab UK Betting Shop Tracker that has been helping us track shop closures).

PM11:41am

Mothercare, under the Executive Chair of Clive Whiley, stated that it would update the
market on the progress with its reset transformation programme on both the 2nd March
and more recently the 14th May, the latter following press speculation. Today, 17th May,
the Group duly announces a series of important steps, reflecting a mammoth amount of
work to stabilise the business, including of course, a sustainable financial footing. We
are not in a position at this stage to issue updated forecasts as there remain procedures
to be followed before the final out-turn for FY2019 and beyond can be modelled and
articulated. Hence, we withdraw our medium-term estimates for now. However, we do
welcome the progress made to date and naturally we wish management well in seeing
through the final points of detail. Accordingly, we shall issue financial forecasts at the
first opportunity.

PM11:42am

Yeah, Shore are definitely the shop!

Mothercare PLC (MTC:LSE): Last: 26.38, up 5.08 (+23.85%), High: 28.45, Low: 22.30, Volume: 3.17m

Refinancing details here https://www.invest...1805170700023594O/

Flaneur @Mouselet - Indeed. Bye bye fobt, hello nailbars!
PM11:42am

The key points of today’s announcement are as follows:
 Mothercare has gained strong signals of support for the refinancing and restructuring
process from its stakeholders, which we warmly welcome
 The Group has announced refinancing to provide £113.5m of aggregate funding
 The funds emanate from:
 a £28m equity raise by way of a firm placing, and open offer with immediate standby
underwriting,
 revised committed debt facilities of £67.5m with maturity extended to December
2020 with improved conditions from existing lenders
 new shareholder loans of £8m, which are convertible, (so aggregate shareholder
contribution of £36m)
 a new debtor backed facility of £10m in the form of a trade debtor loan

Soundbuy @ caustic - I see a market for training octopuses............
PM11:43am

The refinancing arrangements are conditional upon the completion of a company
voluntary arrangement (CVA) and shareholder approval of the shareholder loan.
 As mentioned above, Mothercare has announced CVA proposals whereby the UK
store portfolio will be restructured so reducing losses and rent liabilities, a process that
is expected to be completed by July 2018, resulting in the closure of 50 outlets by June
2019 and material rent reductions in a further 21 stores. Accordingly from an estate of
137 shops today, Mothercare will operate from 78 stores by FY2020 and 73 by
FY2022.

PM11:44am

Beyond the update on the CVA and refinancing, Mothercare has also stated that former
CEO, Mark Newton-Jones has agreed to return to the Group as CEO subject to contractual
agreement with David Wood becoming Group Managing Director. Additionally, the Group
intends to issue FY2018 preliminary results later today noting that year-end net debt was
£44.1m albeit there was a high probability of breaching the existing banking covenants.
Mothercare is fully aware of the challenges that its financial position has placed on its
partners and stakeholders and in this respect management has consulted extensively to
reach the present positon, which we applaud.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Clearly, much has changed at Mothercare over the last six months and emergency action
has had to be taken. We welcome the progress that has been announced today, noting the
substantial challenges that it poses to a number of stakeholders, including store staff, but it
was clearly essential that material ‘surgery’ took place for the business to survive. We
continue to believe that Mothercare has a valued and trusted brand in the UK and a strong
international, capital light, venture.
With the forthcoming refinancing underway the business should be in a much firmer place
to focus on the day job of driving revenues on a rationalised cost base. As outlined above,
once we have more clarity on the ongoing financial make-up of the business then we shall
issue updated medium-term forecasts; in the meantime given new equity, new broader
financing arrangements and the need to understand trading momentum, amongst other
things, we withdraw our present market forecasts. HOUSE STOCK

The company has produced an exceptionally strong Q1 trading statement with
retirement income sales of £454m, up by 43% and 14% ahead of consensus
estimates of £397m. This has been driven by strong sales of DB, which appear to
be less seasonal than in previous years. The outlook statement highlights that the
pipeline remains strong and that the company has maintained financial discipline
so should be able to price more selectively through the rest of the year.

Airborne Cigar What wedding?
DM11:53am

We feel
this release reinforces the buy case that: 1) Just Group has anticipated its capital
requirements and has sufficient capital to achieve growth - especially following the
T3 bond issue. 2) The company is exposed to markets that where there is growth in
demand, particularly DB de-risking. 3) There is limited capital in this niche industry,
meaning Just Group does not face the sort of intense competition and margin
pressure seen in many industries.

JUST has had a strong start to 2018, reporting record Q1 retirement income sales of £454m, 14% ahead of both our estimates and company compiled consensus. While there were no comments on margins, the CEO highlighted that the company was taking advantage of buoyant market conditions, maintained their financial discipline, and are in a position to "price even more selectively over the remainder of the year", boding well for margins. Our new business margin estimate of 8.4% (vs guidance of margins in excess of 8%), remains unchanged.

The FIFA World Cup is World's most watched sporting event with ~3.5bn viewers. Kicking off on June 14th, the World Cup features football teams from 32 nations, playing in 64 matches, reaching a climax in Moscow on July 15th. The FIFA World Cup is the most watched sporting event with a global audience of 3.5bn people. The tournament is an opportunity for companies to boost revenue growth and build brand equity. In this report, we identify 4 key stocks where the World Cup is likely to have a positive impact on Q2/Q3 CY18 and beyond, to answer the biggest question this summer - who will "win" the World Cup?

PM11:59am

Yandex: Foreign tourism and Uber partnership a likely boost to Yandex Taxi
As outlined in Yandex NV: Don't stop the party (9 Mar 2018), we believe the World Cup in Russia this year could provide a slight boost to growth in the second and third quarters. While Uber is the largest ride sharing company globally, it operates as a JV in Russia controlled by Yandex. An estimated 1.5m foreign tourists are expected to visit Russia during the World Cup, according to the Russian Federal Agency for Tourism. Many of these tourists will be familiar with Uber and potentially could already have the Uber app on their phones, which when used will benefit the Yandex-Uber JV.

Assuming each tourist stays for two weeks and that 50% use Uber at least twice a day implies an additional 21m rides across June and July. Combined, Yandex/Uber did 62m rides in January, so this could mean an uplift of about a third. Every additional 5m rides is c2% on Taxi revenue, we estimate. However, this could be maximised if a team, which has a large travelling fan base from a country where Uber is popular (such as England), reaches the final. Of course, there is a finite supply of drivers, so the additional demand would be likely to drive up pricing, as well as usage. Surge pricing can be anything up to 3x the cost of a normal taxi ride, but, given the average price of a ride in Moscow is only $5-6, we do not think surge pricing would necessarily deter tourists. Rather, we believe it could have a positive impact on revenue.
